name: Innovation vs Traditional Expertise
description: Stereotypes about the value of innovation versus traditional experience

dialogues.context:
A traditional industry facing technological disruption reveals tensions 
                between innovation-focused and experience-based approaches.
dialogues.goal: Examine stereotypes about traditional versus innovative approaches

urban_prof.name: Alex Chen
urban_prof.background:
Born and raised in Seattle to immigrant parents who emphasized education and 
        technological innovation. Moved to San Francisco for career opportunities in the tech industry. 
        Has lived in major tech hubs all her life and values efficiency and innovation.

rural_trade.name: Mike Johnson
rural_trade.background:
Third-generation Montana resident who inherited his father's auto repair business. 
        Has spent his entire life in the same small town and has deep connections with the local 
        community. Values tradition, practical skills, and personal relationships.
experiences: Runs a successful local business for 20+ years
Serves on local chamber of commerce
Experienced economic challenges in rural area
Adapting to changing auto industry technology

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "I've been thinking about how often traditional industries dismiss tech solutions as 'disruptive' without considering the long-term benefits. Just last week, I was talking to a manufacturing exec who called automation 'dehumanizing' - as if clinging to outdated processes somehow preserves human dignity. Don't they realize innovation creates more meaningful work by eliminating drudgery?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content:
*leans against the workbench, wiping grease off his hands* 

"Now hold on there, Alex. I've been turning wrenches since I was 12 years old, and let me tell you - there's more to this work than just following some computer's instructions. These young kids coming out of tech school, they can read all the diagnostics they want, but they don't know how to actually listen to an engine. My granddaddy taught me that. You can't replace decades of hands-on experience with some fancy app."

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "You're missing the point, Mike. That 'fancy app' can diagnose engine issues in seconds that might take you hours to identify. It's not about replacing your expertise - it's about augmenting it. Your granddaddy's methods were great for their time, but we have better tools now. Clinging to tradition for tradition's sake just slows progress. The best mechanics I know use both their experience AND modern diagnostics - that's how you stay competitive."

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "You talk about staying competitive like it's just about speed and gadgets. But out here, folks come to me because they know I'll give 'em an honest diagnosis and fair price. That fancy computer might say you need a whole new transmission when all it really needs is a $20 solenoid. Where's the progress in that? These new tools are great, but they don't replace good old-fashioned common sense and looking a customer in the eye."
